item.title: arp-scan
item.description: arp-scan is an [[networks/ARP]] oriented network scanner. Opts - arp-scan -l (--localnet) - sends ARP queries to all valid IP addresses on your local networks

item.title: dig
item.description: dig (Domain Information Groper) is a slightly more powerful tool than [[cybersecurity/knowledge/tools/nslookup]]. 1 $ dig @SERVER DOMAIN_NAME GROUP_TYPE dig returns more information, such as the TTL (Time To Live) by default.

item.title: DNSDumpster
item.description: [!note] DNS lookup tools, such as [[cybersecurity/knowledge/tools/nslookup]] and [[cybersecurity/knowledge/tools/dig]], cannot find subdomains on their own. DNSDumpster is an online servise that offers detailed information for DNS queries.

item.title: masscan
item.description: masscan is a network scanning tool that uses a similar approach to discover the available systems that [[cybersecurity/knowledge/tools/nmap/_index|Nmap]] uses. However, to finish its network scan quickly, Masscan is quite aggressive with the rate of packets it generates.

item.title: netcat
item.description: nc has different applications that can be of great value to a pentester. It supports both TCP and UDP protocols.

item.title: nslookup
item.description: nslookup (Name Server Lookup) is a tool used to find details regarding DNS servers, including but not limited to IPs of particular computers, domain name or aliases.

item.title: ping
item.description: ping is one of the most fundamental network tools. It uses [[cybersecurity/knowledge/glossary/ICMP]] packets to determine the performance of a connection between devices.

item.title: Shodan.io
item.description: Shodan.io can be helpful to learn various pieces of information about the client’s network, without actively connecting to it. We can use different services from Shodan.

item.title: Telnet
item.description: The TELNET (Teletype Network) protocol was developed in 1969 to communicate with a remote system via a CLI. The command telnet uses the TELNET protocol for remote administration that relies on [[TCP]].

item.title: traceroute
item.description: traceroute traces the route taken by the packets from your system to another host. The purpose of a traceroute is to find the IP addresses of the routers or hops that a packet traverses as it goes from your system to a target host.

item.title: WHOIS
item.description: WHOIS is a request and response protocol that follows the RFC 3912 specification. A WHOIS server listens on TCP port 43 for incoming requests.
